newsitem.title: BOSNIA: Bosnian dinar made convertible to hard currency.
newsitem.headline: Bosnian dinar made convertible to hard currency.

text.p: Bosnian citizens won the right to exchange local dinars for hard currency for the first time this week, Bosnia's National Bank vice-governor said on Friday.
"The decision is effective for all 40 business banks in the Moslem-Croat federation from December 5," vice-governor Obrad Piljak told Reuters.
Piljak said there were no limits on currency purchases but some banks put a daily ceiling on transactions of 1,000 German marks, the only foreign currency available.
"This will help restore citizens' confidence in their banks and help them solve their problems at bank counters and not on the black market," he said.
The official exchange rate is 100 dinars for one German Mark. It was set in 1994 and was linked to a rigorous monetary policy of only issuing dinars covered by mark reserves, Piljak said.

The last time Bosnians were able to purchase hard currency was in 1990 when Bosnia, then one of Yugoslavia's republics, was experiencing a brief economic revival under prime minister Ante Markovic, who made the Yugoslav currency convertible.
Fighting broke out in 1991 in Slovenia and Croatia as Yugoslavia's break-up began. Hard currency savings were frozen and customers were unable to withdraw or purchase any foreign funds.
Bosnia-Hercegovina is made up of the Moslem-Croat federation, which rules 51 percent of the territory and a Serb republic in the remaining 49 percent.

The two parts were supposed to be united under the 1995 peace accord and to have one central bank and a single currency. But progress on joint institutions has remained slow and the Serb republic uses Yugoslav dinars as their local money.
German marks remain the common currency among the divided communities.
Before conversion was allowed people used the black market to buy hard currency at 110 or 120 dinars to the mark.
The national bank's decision is meant to draw bank customers away from the black market and stabilise the value of the dinar.
The banks charge two percent commission for the purchase, selling one DEM for 102 dinars.
